To determine the implied interest rate needed to make a value of $10,000 today equal to $11,000 one year from now, we can use the formula for present value:
PV = FV / (1 + r)^n
Where:
PV = present value (i.e., $10,000 today)
FV = future value (i.e., $11,000 one year from now)
r = implied interest rate
n = number of periods (i.e., 1 year)
Since you provided the values of $10,000 today and $11,000 one year from now, we can plug those values into the formula to solve for the implied interest rate:
PV = $10,000 / (1 + r)^1 = $11,000 / (1 + r)^1
Now, we can solve for the implied interest rate "r" by dividing both sides of the equation by $10,000:
r = (1 + r)^1 / $10,000 = $11,000 / $10,000 = 11%
Therefore, the implied interest rate needed to make a value of $10,000 today equal to $11,000 one year from now is 11%.
